comments.body: @acozine @chouseknecht **If** this PR as a whole gets deferred to 2.10, should the above two changes be pushed into 2.9.x separately?  It seems like it fixes an independent documentation bug.
I am pretty positive that the change to give a default install path will not be accepted for 2.9, potentially not even for 2.10.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +251,255 @@.. code-block:: bash

   ansible-galaxy collection install my_namespace-my_collection-1.0.0.tar.gz -p ./collections

comments.body: This would be so common (builds of past versions), I'd argue that it would be nice to have it in the default ignore list.

The trouble with the default ignore list is you cannot overwrite it. This would stop anyone from using a collection that had roles or playbooks that contained these files (and weren't an actual collection release).

Although running `ansible-galaxy collection build` **will** ignore `{namespace}-{name}-*.tar.gz` in the root directory so unless someone is building the collection in another dir it should be ignored on subsequent builds.
ok I see how that makes sense now. Looks like the .tar.gz I found was from an alternative namespace, so that's why the rule you mention didn't filter it out.

```suggestion
    * Certain files and folders are excluded when building the collection artifact. See :ref:`ignoring_files_and_folders_collections` to exclude other files you do not wish to distribute.
```

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +235,239 @@
.. note::
    * Certain files and folders are excluded when building the collection artifact. See :ref:`ignoring_files_and_folders_collections`  to exclude other files you would not wish to distribute.
    * If you used the now-deprecated ``Mazer`` tool for any of your collections, delete any and all files it added to your :file:`releases/` directory before you build your collection with ``ansible-galaxy``.
    * The current Galaxy maximum tarball size is 2 MB.

comments.body:
```suggestion
For collections hosted in the ``ansible-collections`` GitHub org, create a branch and commit your changes on the branch. When you are done (remember to add tests, see :ref:`testing_collections`), push your changes to your fork of the collection and create a Pull Request. For other collections, especially for collections not hosted on GitHub, check the ``README.md`` of the collection for information on contributing to it.
```
It's https://github.com/ansible-collections/ with a dash.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +593,597 @@Now you can use this checkout of ``community.general`` in playbooks and roles with whichever version of Ansible you have installed locally, including a local checkout of the ``devel`` branch.

For collections hosted in the ``ansible_collections`` GitHub org, create a branch and commit your changes on the branch. When you are done (remember to add tests, see :ref:`testing_collections`), push your changes to your fork of the collection and create a Pull Request. For other collections, especially for collections not hosted on GitHub, check the ``README.md`` of the collection for information on contributing to it.

comments.body: Won't this add another heading `Installing collections from a git repository from the shared segment?

You can't install more than one collection from a repo, can you?
```suggestion
Installing a collection from a git repository
---------------------------------------------
```
Yes, you can. Either by having multiple directories with galaxy.yml files in the root of the repo or by adding a fragment to the URI.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +343,347 @@
Installing collections from a git repository
--------------------------------------------

You can also test a version of your collection in development by installing it from a git repository.
